Mars

Discover Mars

Named after the Roman god of war, our second-smallest big brother planet Mars was the first planet we incorporated in our destination brochures. Mars' terrestrial surface is covered in iron oxide, giving it its signature red color. Its rare bloody appearance was often confused as a Deus ex Machina, revitalizing pinned down troops to turn the tables on their enemies.

Many geographical sites still bear Classical names. Our first Mars base is located in a 820km wide field of plains called the Aeolis Planum. Those wide landscapes are the ideal place to start your Mars exploration tours, and also forms the final stop of our Mars Rover package.

Olympus Mons - which sits at a height of 24km, about three times as high as Mt. Everest - forms the location of our other Mars holiday base. While not for the faint of heart, the hiking trails that start from Base Olympus are arguably the best experience we offer on the Red Planet.

Venus

Discover Venus

The second terrestrial holiday destination on the list is our sister-planet Venus. It has been made sacred to gods of many cultures, and has been a prime inspiration for writers and poets as the morning star and evening star. Venus was the first planet to have its motions plotted across the sky, as early as the second millennium BC.

Despite its similar size, mass and proximity to the sun, Venus bears a lot of radical differences to our planet Earth. The mean surface temperature approximates a stunning 462°C, and the athmospheric pressure can be compared to the pressure found at 900m below sea level on our humble globe.

Those circumstances are challenging to face, but the geographical sites to explore are worth all the effort. Much of the Venusian surface was shaped by volcanic activity. Roughly 80% of the planet is covered by volcanic plains, holding 167 volcanoes larger than the biggest volcano on earth, and several more smaller ones. Our Venus Flytrap package offers a tour of Maat Mons, the largest Venusian volcano, siting at an altitude of 8km.

No words can describe the sights you will experience on the way there and back, so do not miss out on our next launch window and grab your chance to see it all for yourself!

Neptunus

Discover Neptunus

Our latest addition, Neptune, had been in development with our science team for the last 15 years. Not only is it the planet farthest away from our Sun, but it is also the first non-terrestrial planet on our list, with an atmosphere composed primarily of hydrogen and helium.

Our Neptune Deep Dive package takes you on a high-speed ride through the stormy climate of the blue planet, with winds reaching speeds of almost 600 m/s (2,200 km/h; 1,300 mph)—nearly reaching supersonic flow.

Our very first commercial launch is set for this summer, and we do not want to spoil any of the fun for the first crew. Included in the package is a two day bootcamp of High-G training. A final piece of advice: please keep your arms down during the whole ride; our onboard medical team is not specialized in the reattachment of larger body parts.
